Description: A daisy decorates the interior of a tazza, or footed dish.  A point on the bottom of the saucer fits into a corresponding depression in the stand, securing the two together.  Patterns cut into the still moist composition were filled with a different colored paste to create the inlay.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Gifts of the Nile: Ancient Egypian Faience
Exhibitions.Textblock: Gifts of the Nile: Ancient Egypian Faience. The Cleveland Museum of Art, Cleveland; Museum of Art, Rhode Island School of Design, Providence; Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth. 1998-1999.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Egypt's Golden Age: The Art of Living in the New Kingdom (1558-1085 B.C.)
Exhibitions.Textblock: Egypt's Golden Age: The Art of Living in the New Kingdom (1558-1085 B.C.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Boston; Houston Museum of Natural Science, Houston; The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1982-1983.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Egypt's Dazzling Sun: Amenhotep III and His World
Exhibitions.Textblock: Egypt's Dazzling Sun: Amenhotep III and His World. The Cleveland Museum of Art, Cleveland; Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth; Galeries nationales du Grand Palais, Paris. 1992-1993.

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Centre Street: Second Floor: Egyptian Art

Provenance: E. A. Abemayor, Cairo [date and mode of aquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1930; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Blue Faience Saucer and Stand
